article.headline: Washington State 75, Arizona State 55
article.story: PULLMAN, Wash. (AP) -- The Washington State Cougars, known for their gritty defense, came out sizzling on offense Thursday night, routing Arizona State 75-55. The Cougars buried seven of their first eight shots, including their first four 3-pointers, and improved to 13-2 overall and 2-1 in the Pacific-10 Conference. "If we hadn't been shooting like we were in the first half, we could have really been in trouble," said Robbie Cowgill, who led WSU with 16 points. "That was kind of our saving grace in the first half, because we didn't play great defensively." Jeff Pendergraph sank all eight of his shots from the field and led Arizona State (6-8, 0-3) with 16 points and seven rebounds. Christian Polk added 13 points, all in the first half. No other ASU player scored more than seven points in the Sun Devils' fourth consecutive loss. The Sun Devils shot 62 percent from the field in the first half and 55 percent for the game, while WSU countered with 54 percent shooting in the first half and 54 percent for the game. Washington State led 37-33 at the half, then cruised to victory after a 9-0 run early in the second half put the Cougars up 48-37. Derrick Low scored 14 points and had a season-high seven assists for WSU. Daven Harmeling added 13 points, and reserve Caleb Forrest tied his career high with 11 points. "We had a very tough time defending Washington State," ASU coach Herb Sendek said. "We tried a variety of defenses, none of which were effective." "We shot the ball extremely well -- but we're a defensive team," Cougars coach Tony Bennett said. "We can't allow a team to shoot 62 percent from the field in the first half." Bennett credited reserve forward Ivory Clark with shutting down Polk in the second half. Forrest, who was averaging just two points and eight minutes per game, played 14 minutes in the second half and matched the career-high 11 points he scored last season at Arizona State. "Caleb gave us a great boost," Bennett said. "That's a young man who has hardly played. He doesn't say a word, he just battles in practice nonstop." "I always keep telling myself, it's a heck of an opportunity to be playing at Washington State," Forrest said. WSU had a 22-7 advantage in points off turnovers and a 16-6 edge in turnovers. The Cougars wound up 8 for 16 on 3-pointers, with Low hitting 4 of 6 and Harmeling sinking 3 of 4. The 20-point margin of victory was WSU's largest in a Pac-10 game since a 98-76 win over Washington on March 1, 2003. The 13-2 start is WSU's best since a 15-2 start in 1982-83.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
